title.rendered: Historic Hiring News: Abrams for Governor Campaign Announces American Sign Language Interpreter Position, Further Diversifies Disability Accessibility

content.rendered:
ATLANTA – On Tuesday, the Abrams for Governor campaign announced a new position for a full time American Sign Language Interpreter. The position, one of the first on a political campaign in the nation, will aid the campaign in interpreting services for both in-person and virtual events. 

“Abrams for Governor is committed to ensuring that the disability community here in Georgia, a community that has too often been harmed and forgotten, is an integral part of the work that we do,” said Dom Kelly, Director of Disability Engagement and Accessibility. “We hope that by leading the way in hiring a full-time American Sign Language interpreter to our staff, Deaf, Deaf-Blind, and hard of hearing Georgians will know that as governor, Stacey Abrams will never leave them behind. The fight for disability rights has never been more important. We are committed to being at the forefront of this work here in Georgia by building an inclusive and accessible campaign.”

In March, the Abrams for Governor campaign released its Disability Rights platform. As governor, Stacey Abrams will work in partnership with the disability community in Georgia to fulfill the promises of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): equal opportunity, full participation, independent living, and economic self-sufficiency. Abrams understands that an effective government must protect civil rights and fight discrimination based on disability.

Background on Stacey Abrams’ Disability Rights Platform:

  • Increase Disability Protections: Advance economic security for disabled Georgians by ending the practice of subminimum wages and defend disabled Georgians by enforcing fair wage payments.
  • Affordable and Accessible Housing: Create incentives to increase the supply of affordable and accessible housing that can meet the needs of disabled Georgians and hold landlords accountable for discriminatory practices.
  • Support People Coping with Long Covid: Champion protections for people with Long Covid to ensure that treatment is accessible and affordable and that federal anti-discrimination laws are enforced in cases when Long Covid becomes a disability.
  • Expand Medicaid: Increase access to a full range of medical and mental healthcare for Georgians, including disabled people.

Those interested in applying for the American Sign Language Interpreter position may visit here.

###
